abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that the project
            clearly demonstrated the benefits of natural resource
            management practices for smallholders in the Andean sierra
            of Peru. For projects with a significant institutional
            development objective, there needs to be strong commitment
            by the implementing agency with actions and time programmed
            in the first years of the project to achieve the changes
            intended. One handicap to implementation is the lack of
            clear definition of new concepts and practices, which in
            this case included participatory planning and
            micro-catchment management. Investment in works can easily
            crowd out attention by project implementors to more
            difficult institutional development objectives as was the
            case in this project. Involving an external agency in
            assisting communities in procurement should be done under
            strict limitations and guidelines. In spite of an excellent
            social assessment during preparation, and the inclusion of
            the recommendations of that assessment in the project
            design, the project impact was minimal in increasing the
            historically low levels of women's involvement in
            natural resource management efforts.
